results.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column on sugary public romantic moments between Al and Tipper Gore, and inevitable contrast with rocky marriage of Bill and Hillary Clinton; adds that only couple that cannot campaign as couple this year is couple that sparked current obsession with couplehood (M)
results.snippet: It was a tip-top Tipper moment.    Al Gore was appearing with his wife on Larry King's show Thursday, leaning closer and closer to her.
results.lead_paragraph: It was a tip-top Tipper moment. Al Gore was appearing with his wife on Larry King's show Thursday, leaning closer and closer to her.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery is set to blast off for the embryonic International Space Station on a mission that will represent milestones for both the reusable space plane and its destination; Discovery's 28th trip into space will also be 100th flight for space shuttle program, and mission, which involves hauling up nine-ton exterior framework for station and three-ton docking port, begins new phase in expanding orbital research outpost; photos (M)

headline.main: On Flight No. 100, the Shuttle Goes Back to Its Roots

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery is set to blast off on Thursday for the embryonic International Space Station, a mission that will represent milestones for both the reusable space plane and its destination.    The Discovery's 28th trip into space will...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery is set to blast off on Thursday for the embryonic International Space Station, a mission that will represent milestones for both the reusable space plane and its destination. The Discovery's 28th trip into space will also be the 100th flight for the space shuttle program, and the mission, which involves hauling up a nine-ton exterior framework for the station and a three-ton docking port, begins a new phase in expanding the orbital research outpost.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum....
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum. Opening tomorrow, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' live, multicolored butterflies from Africa, Asia and the Americas on view in the rain forest of the Butterfly Conservatory; through May 28. Tickets, which include museum admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children, 2 to 12; under 2 free. Advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs from the 1920's and 30's by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews. Through Dec. 30. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

results.abstract: Online Shopper column describes internal family squabbles over Halloween costumes; discusses shopping online for holiday garb; drawing (M)

headline.main: More Than Fake Blood and Bunny Ears

results.snippet: IT'S no secret around my neighborhood that when it comes to Halloween, my family has problems. I wish I could say that the quarrels the neighbors overhear are confined to such trivial issues as what color Jell-O to use in the human-brain mold or...
results.lead_paragraph: IT'S no secret around my neighborhood that when it comes to Halloween, my family has problems. I wish I could say that the quarrels the neighbors overhear are confined to such trivial issues as what color Jell-O to use in the human-brain mold or whose turn it is to wear the light-up werewolf fangs. But actually, clashes over costumes have escalated to an extent I would not have thought possible back in the days when my daughters were willing to wear any old bunny outfit I picked up at the drugstore.

results.abstract: Home Video column on two documentaries, Allen and Albert Hughes's American Pimp, and A Place Called Chiapas, Nettie Wild's study of Zapatista uprising in Mexico (S)
results.snippet: Worlds apart in all other respects, two first-rate documentaries released on Tuesday are equally savvy in working their territories.     In ''American Pimp,'' the Hughes Brothers (Allen and Albert) fan out from coast to coast for a sweeping survey of...
results.lead_paragraph: Worlds apart in all other respects, two first-rate documentaries released on Tuesday are equally savvy in working their territories. In ''American Pimp,'' the Hughes Brothers (Allen and Albert) fan out from coast to coast for a sweeping survey of about a dozen alternately odious and hilarious managers of the world's oldest profession. And deep in the Mexican countryside, Nettie Wild plays a quiet waiting game in ''A Place Called Chiapas,'' her study of the Zapatista uprising in the 1990's.

results.abstract: Jeffrey Kastner interviews artist Matthew Ritchie, whose major exhibitions since 1995 have focused on adventurous story lines and whose latest, Parents and Children, is set to open at Andrea Rosen Gallery in New York City; photo (M)

headline.main: An Adventurer's Map to a World of Information

results.snippet: IT'S all made up,'' Matthew Ritchie says with a characteristically inscrutable grin as he settles into a chair in his Chelsea studio. ''Except for all the parts that are true.''    It's a late summer afternoon, and Mr. Ritchie is taking a break from...
results.lead_paragraph: IT'S all made up,'' Matthew Ritchie says with a characteristically inscrutable grin as he settles into a chair in his Chelsea studio. ''Except for all the parts that are true.'' It's a late summer afternoon, and Mr. Ritchie is taking a break from preparations for his forthcoming show at the nearby Andrea Rosen Gallery, helping a visitor unravel fact from fiction in his sprawling artistic program. At first glance, Mr. Ritchie's ambitious paintings, drawings and installations seem to illustrate an impenetrable personal cosmology. Yet they're built on a rigorous system of real-world information, ranging from theoretical physics and molecular biology to medieval alchemy and classical philosophy. According to the artist, it's just the beginning of a continuing project designed to function as nothing less than ''a map of everything.''

results.abstract: Article discusses how New Yorkers who were not able to get tickets for World Series are managing to follow series via television or radio; photo (M)
results.snippet: For one of those rarest of times, the people of this city spent the night together. Beneath a blanket woven by electronic transmissions and draped over skyscrapers and bodegas, they followed an athletic drama unfolding dreamily in the bluish Bronx...
results.lead_paragraph: For one of those rarest of times, the people of this city spent the night together. Beneath a blanket woven by electronic transmissions and draped over skyscrapers and bodegas, they followed an athletic drama unfolding dreamily in the bluish Bronx haze of one Saturday night in autumn. Tucked under that blanket was a woman in a cancer hospital in Manhattan, a Mets cap in her lap and an anxious knot in her chest. Joining her was a gaggle of young people in the Bronx, unable to sit still in a street-corner theater created with a small television set and a long electrical cord.

results.abstract: Dave Anderson, in Sports of The Times, holds New York Mets should be in World Series parade in lower Manhattan next week, as well as world champion New York Yankees; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Parade Needs the Mets to Be Participants Too

results.snippet: NOW that this World Series in New York, New York is over, the Mets -- not just the champion Yankees -- should also be in next week's parade up Lower Broadway to City Hall.    In three of the previous four years, as every Yankee devotee knows,...
results.lead_paragraph: NOW that this World Series in New York, New York is over, the Mets -- not just the champion Yankees -- should also be in next week's parade up Lower Broadway to City Hall. In three of the previous four years, as every Yankee devotee knows, thousands of Noo Yawkers turned out to honor the Yankees at a Lower Broadway parade after World Series victories. Quite understandably, nobody cared much about the losing teams in those years because they represented Atlanta, San Diego and Atlanta again.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,''...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Tomorrow night at 7:30, ''Halloween Mystery Night,'' party and festivities. Admission: $12; $10 for members. Reservations required. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

results.abstract: Russian and American astronauts prepare to blast off from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to dock with new orbiting International Space Station on four-month shakedown mission to make it habitable; US astronaut Capt William M Shepherd will enter craft as first commander; Russian cosmonaut Yuri P Gidzenko will command Soyuz spacecraft on two-day trip to station; will control rendezvous and docking; Sergei K Krikalev will serve as flight engineer; $60 billion space station being constructed by 16 nations led by US and Russia is currently 143-foot-long structure of linked modules weighing 162,000 pounds; will be expanded to mass of 1 million pounds over next five years, covering area larger than football field and will include at least four major scientific modules (M)

headline.main: Russian and U.S. Crew Ready To Blast Off to Space Station

results.snippet: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost.    The three-man crew of astronauts from Russia and the United...
results.lead_paragraph: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost. The three-man crew of astronauts from Russia and the United States is scheduled to lift off aboard a Russian Soyuz rocket from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan at 2:53 a.m., Eastern time, on Tuesday. If all goes well, this Expedition One crew will dock with the new space station early Thursday to begin a four-month shakedown mission to make the spacecraft habitable.
